channel.title: Home on Yan's Homepage
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Yan's Homepage

item.title: Another Note on A blogdown Tutorial
item.description: I just discovered an awesome tutorial on blogdown written by Alison. I have to admit this is the best blogdown tutorial I have seen so far.

item.title: A Quick Note on Two Beautiful Websites
item.description: To me, the two most impressive websites based on blogdown are: Rob J Hyndman’s personal website. Live Free or Dichotomize by Lucy and Nick et al. I’m sure there will be more.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This sample post is mainly for blogdown users. If you do not use blogdown, you can skip the first section. 1. Markdown or R Markdown This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.

item.title: Industry
item.description: Research Intern I have been fortunate enough to play with some interesting and challenging optimization tasks for training neural recommendation models at an industrial scale. These recommenders, along with their embedding tables, easily exceed Trillion bytes in size. Training at this scale creates many interesting stochastic and distributed optimization problems, and calls for usecase-dependent method development. Research Intern, Facebook (Meta), Ads Ranking Date: May 2021 - Nov 2021. Mentor: Dr.

item.title: Misc
item.description: Outside Research I occasionally lift with optimizers Hongzhang, Chungjae and Kaizhao, unfortunately I’m also prone to injury. Job search is brutal, I lost around 18 pounds in 2 months. I play ok-level badminton, and (barely) entry-level basketball. Before joining ISyE PhD program, I passed the real analysis comprehensive exam (Spring 2017, pass ratio 7/13) of PhD program in Math at Georgia Tech.

item.title: Research
item.description: .custom-list { padding: 0; margin: 0; } .custom-list li { margin-bottom: 8px; /* space between items */ padding-left: 40px; /* Add desired padding value */ list-style-type: none; /* Remove default bullet point */ } .custom-list li::before { content: "â€¢"; /* Add bullet point character */ display: inline-block; width: 10px; /* Adjust bullet point width */ text-align: center; margin-left: -20px; /* Adjust negative margin to remove space */ } Research Overview My research focuses on the design and analysis of novel data-driven first-order methods to support robust and efficient decision making under uncertainty.

item.title: Talks
item.description: Slides __SIAM Conference on Optimization__ (OP23, June 2023, Seattle) - Policy Mirror Descent Inherectly Explores Action Space (Tentative) - Host: Prof. Zhaoran Wang (Northwestern University), Prof. George Lan (Georgia Tech)   Slides __ISyE PhD Student Seminar__ (GaTech, April 2023, Atlanta) - Policy Mirror Descent Inherectly Explores Action Space - Student host: Xinyu Liu, Sourabh Choudhary   Slides __INFORMS Annual Meeting__ (INFORMS, October 2022, Indianapolis) - Homotopic Policy Mirror Descent: Policy Convergence, Implicit Regularization, and Improved Sample Complexity - Host: Prof.

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Instructor ISYE 3770: Statistics and Applications, Spring 2023, Georgia Tech Introductory probability and statistics course for engineering-majored students. Class size: 69. Teaching evaluation: 4.8/5.0, but personally more proud of the kind words I received from students in the CISO survey. Design curriculum, lecture notes, homeworks, and exams. I believe in the essential role of white-board discussion for teaching mathematical content. Kindly find my self-designed syllabus and lecture notes here.
